📅 Day 17 of 17 #SDGs Goal 17: Partnerships to achieve the Goal. 
The #nuclear industry conducts outreach with developing countries and has partnerships with governments, NGOs and UN bodies. An example is the International Framework for Nuclear Energy Cooperation. ⚛️ https://t.co/1BIahS3NLH
If we can achieve that, nuclear can help provide affordable, abundant and clean energy to all, equitably. #COP27 #ATOMS4CLIMATE.

Sama says @WorldNuclear will look forward to working with other nuclear associations and nuclear companies to accelerate the deployment of nuclear energy. That will also mean talking to others - the finance community, regulators and governments.

Finally, @SamaBilbao reflects on #COP27. It’s the first time nuclear has had a large pavilion in the ‘blue zone’. It’s has given the opportunity to present nuclear, and discuss nuclear with many different stakeholders. https://t.co/LgOcfOJDKZ
Maryam Qasem @ENEC_UAE looks forward to welcoming delegates to #COP28 next year in Dubai and showcasing nuclear’s contribution to the UAE’s decarbonisation. https://t.co/1amdA75fZi

Tyson Culver, @TysonCulver Director of Juice, says the nuclear industry needs to learn to humblebrag, and be more outgoing and clear in communicating its benefits. #COP27 #ATOMS4CLIMATE https://t.co/VbxaF3Ljon
Joanne Osawe WIRE @WiRE_Canada welcomes the partnership between her renewable association and @WiNglobal and how SMRs and renewables can work together. #COP27 https://t.co/HZmkZTw9du

Angela Wilkinson @WECouncil looks to raise the profile of energy transitions and additions. Multiple pathways will be needed and more clean energy will be needed - nuclear, hydro, gas with CCS, hydrogen.

Daniel Liu from #JAIF notes Asia is one of the biggest nuclear markets in the world, but the sector is underrepresented at COP, but the #ATOMS4CLIMATE booth has given some companies from the region an opportunity to get involved. https://t.co/1MfYmoWexR
Allan Woods @RollsRoyce highlights suitability of SMRs for countries with lower overall electricity demand.
Elina Teplinsky @pillsburylaw said that nuclear has been here at COP27 with its own pavilions, but in the future needs to be on other pavilions more, including country pavilions.

Tony Roberts @urencoglobal says it’s is great to see nuclear as an increasing part of the conversation at #COP27. Urenco is working to ensure the full fuel supply chain is low carbon. As a business, URENCO targets net zero by 2040. https://t.co/mviTYeqoGu

Carlos Leipner @cleanaircatf notes energy growth will be spurred in large part to meet the development needs of countries that don’t have sufficient electricity supplies at present. https://t.co/TZfXIXKzAQ
Beyond COP27 - #nuclear’s contribution to sustainable development with @SamaBilbao is live at #ATOMS4CLIMATE AT #COP27 https://t.co/E4VnHKu821

Today we have our final event at @COP27 on #ATOMS4CLIMATE starting at 08:30 GMT, DG @SamaBilbao will be interviewing a range of speakers from @cleanaircatf @urencoglobal, @WECouncil, @RollsRoyce, @pillsburylaw, @ENEC_UAE, & many more

https://t.co/lyWRet6SQ3

📅 Day 14 of 17 #SDGs Goal 5: Gender Equality​⚛️​

#Nuclear companies have signed up to initiatives encouraging young women to move into STEM careers, and to provide training to prevent discrimination and fight against bias.

https://t.co/2scoqSOCiG https://t.co/E97Hl94jSn

However, Lisa McBride notes that girls and young women are still disuaded from careers in STEM. She also observes that there are no men on the panel, and the discussion needs to involve men and well as women.
Laura Holgate notes that there's improved gender balance among STEM graduates, but there are challenges in retaining women in the STEM fields, what she calls the "leaky pipeline."
Joanna Osage highlights the programmes and activities run by WIRE, including collaboration with Women in Nuclear.
Princess Mthombeni recalls how she used to spend a lot of time getting clean water. Improving access to clean water allows girls and women use their time more productively.
Maryam Qasem reflects on the equal opportunities offered to women and men in ENEC’ nuclear engineering training.
Laura Holgate highlights how climate change disproportionately impacts women and girls.

. @SamaBilbao  introduces Laura Holgate, US Ambassador to the Vienna Office of the UN and to IAEA; Maryam Qasem, ENEC; Lisa McBride, WIN Canada; Princess Mthombeni; Joanna Osage, Women in Renewable Energy and Soheir Korra, WIN Global. https://t.co/FN6D7v0EOI

📅 Day 5 of 17 #SDGs Goal 10: Reduce inequality within and among countries.

⚛️ Nuclear protects low-income households, which are disproportionately affected by volatile electricity prices.

https://t.co/JMpsFoaAk2 https://t.co/eUykp3ZP3x

⚛️In the latest @W_Nuclear_News podcast episode, Tim Gitzel explains why he thinks the #nuclear industry is up to the challenge of playing a critical role in providing clean energy for generations to come. ⚛️https://t.co/CfzuxDwppG https://t.co/j0AIrUWv1i

⚗️ Hydrogen may also have a significant role to play in future transport systems and heating homes. 
Nuclear reactors can already be used to produce hydrogen by electrolysis, and high-temperature reactors will be able to produce hydrogen through thermo-chemical techniques. ⚛️

🚗 Exhaust fumes from vehicles are a major contributor to air pollution in cities. 
Shifting to electric vehicles increases demand for clean energy. 
The high availability of #nuclear power plants will be an important factor to help recharge electric vehicles ⚛️ https://t.co/cTlWlIvExO

🏙️ Over half the population in world cities endure worsening air pollution. 
Nuclear power plants can also be used for district heating, avoiding pollution from fossil fuels. 
Between 1971 & 2009 Nuclear power plants prevented more than 1.8 million air pollution-related deaths ⚛️ https://t.co/yyD5CDBD5K

📅 Day 4 of 17 #SDGs Goal 11: Make cities and human settlements inclusive, safe, resilient and sustainable.

🏙️ Nuclear helps make cities and human settlements inclusive, safe, resilient and sustainable ⚛️

https://t.co/hKQlioOxld https://t.co/jQKe4sVjfC

🧦 The textile industry consumes huge amounts of water and chemicals. 

Nuclear electron beam technology cleans water by breaking apart chemical bonds of clothing dyes & removes pollutants, allowing recycling of the water. ⚛️

https://t.co/Pu1YlbBsgA

🌊 Desalination of seawater using heat generated by #nuclear reactors produces pure, clean water, without the greenhouse gases emitted by the fossil fuel plants that power desalination units. ⚛️ https://t.co/B37jWjQ1TR

📅 Day 3 of 17 #SDGs Goal 6: Ensure availability & sustainable management of water & sanitation for all.

💧 #Nuclear energy is vital to achieve universal access to clean water & sanitation. ⚛️

https://t.co/JMpsFoaAk2 https://t.co/aBayIb8uH5

💉Sterilization of medical equipment is also an important use of radioisotopes.

The #nuclear by-product cobalt-60 can kill off harmful and deadly bacteria, making it an effective solution to sterilize medical equipment, such as syringes and catheters.

🔬 Biotechnologists analyse specific molecules inside the body using #nuclear materials. These techniques are an essential research component for chronic illnesses like AIDS and Alzheimer’s disease. https://t.co/sVpF9Vsl5a

Over 40 million nuclear medicine procedures are performed each year, and demand for radioisotopes is increasing at up to 5% annually.

https://t.co/RyRZgyYp47

⚛️ Radioisotopes are used for diagnostics & treatment. Diagnostic procedures using radioisotopes are now routine.

Radioisotopes can be produced by #nuclear reactors,
like Australia's OPAL research Reactor: https://t.co/MxXM5dUgxx

Leona Woods (1919-1986) helped build the first nuclear reactor. She was the youngest and only female member of the team which built and experimented with the world's first nuclear reactor, Chicago Pile-1, in a project led by her mentor Enrico Fermi. #IWD2019 #BalanceforBetter https://t.co/kFBzSFSlrv

Chien-Shiung Wu (1912-1997) was an experimental physicist who made significant contributions in the field of nuclear physics.  she helped develop the process for separating uranium metal into uranium-235 and uranium-238 isotopes by gaseous diffusion. #IWD2019 #BalanceforBetter https://t.co/kVd3qoxqjY

Toshiko Yuasa (1909-1980) was the first woman to study physics in Japan. Yuasa was inspired by the discovery of artificial radioactivity by Irène and Frédéric Joliot-Curie at the Radium Institute in Paris. #IWD2019 #BalanceforBetter https://t.co/vrzKRcur3V

Lise Meitner (1878-1968) worked on radioactivity and nuclear physics. Along with her colleagues, Otto Hahn and Otto Robert Frisch, she led the small group of scientists who first discovered nuclear fission of uranium when it absorbed an extra neutron. #IWD2019 #BalanceforBetter https://t.co/Mueyt6PnrA

Marie Curie (1867-1934) conducted pioneering research on radioactivity. She was the first woman to win a Nobel Prize (& the only woman to win it twice in 2 different sciences!). She was the first woman to become a professor at the University of Paris. #IWD2019 #BalanceforBetter https://t.co/QDLu0I3bSd

Today is International Women’s Day #IWD2019 and we’re marking the occasion with a series of posts celebrating some of the most inspiring and successful women in nuclear science. #BalanceforBetter https://t.co/oFqPAgOgdj
